comment: In my preparation to this tournament, I (and probably everybody else) paid the most serious attention to two openingsx Ruy Lopez with Bc5 and Najdorf, since most of the participants seem to play them both. Needless to say, refuting Najdorf is tough, but I thought I came close to refuting Ruy Lopez with 5...b5 and 6...Bc5, provided Black responded to 7.a4 with 7...Rb8. But the opening ceremony dealt a heavy blow to mex I was the last one to play Shirov with White. And indeed, in Rounds 7&8 Shirov faced the position after 7.a4 against Kasparov & Anand. But to my relief, he must have thought that these guys know something and replied 7...Bb7. I was still in business.
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake made by the player as they failed to adapt their strategy despite recognizing that their opponents might be familiar with the Ruy Lopez opening, which led them to lose the game.
context: This is a game between Svidler (as White) and Shirov (as Black). Last move played: Black plays Pawn to e5
reformulated: "In the tournament's opening, I focused on Ruy Lopez with Bc5 and Najdorf. Refuting Najdorf seemed tough, but I believed I had a chance with 5...b5 and 6...Bc5 if Black played 7...Rb8 after 7.a4. However, facing Shirov as White, I assumed he would be familiar with the Najdorf variations from games by Kasparov and Anand. My strategy failed when Shirov opted for 7...Bb7."

Black is completely out of danger.
